description: The Hathaleen (Hathalin) family—part of the Jahalin Bedouin confederation—lived for generations around Tel Arad in the Naqab/Negev.

title: Nakba
description: The family was forcibly expelled from Tel Arad/Naqab after the establishment of Israel; return became institutionally impossible as the area was reclassified under state/military control and later preserved as an "archaeological site/national park," erasing modern Bedouin presence.

title: Establishment of Arad
description: Israel established the Jewish-majority "development town" Arad near Tel Arad, on lands from which Bedouin communities had been expelled; the area was later normalized as a tourism hub for the Dead Sea.

title: Hathaleens Migration
description: The Hathaleens migrated north seeking water and pasture, maintaining a pastoral life (tents, herding) and entering the Hebron hills (then under Jordanian rule), where informal grazing, dwelling-building, and land transactions were not prosecuted in the same way.

title: Hathaleens Migration
description: Israel occupied the West Bank, taking over and restructuring Jordanian-era land and planning systems.

Military Order 418 centralized planning and permit authority under Israeli military/civil administration control, hollowing out Palestinian local planning bodies and making legal building permits in much of Area C nearly unattainable—laying the bureaucratic groundwork for “illegalization.”
After tightened control and restricted mobility, the Hathaleen family built the first dwelling in Umm al-Kheir, legitimized through local transactions, witnesses, and social relations.

Large parts of Masafer Yatta were designated Firing Zone 918 (a “live-fire training zone), renaming civilian land-use as “military use” and enabling restriction and expulsion. An Israeli Nahal military outpost was established near Umm al-Kheir and later transferred to settler institutions (via Amana, affiliated with Gush Emunim), gradually expanding into the civilian settlement Carmel, which came to sit immediately adjacent to the village.

Dec 8. The First Intifada began and spread across Gaza and the West Bank; Israel responded with mass arrests, curfews, and closure—forming a wider template of militarized control that later deepened in Hebron and its rural peripheries.

Sept 13. The Oslo Accords were signed; rather than “peace,” the post-Oslo period brought more checkpoints and movement control in the South Hebron Hills, re-coding everyday routes to markets and villages.

Feb 25. Settler Baruch Goldstein killed 29 Palestinians in the Ibrahimi Mosque in Hebron; Israel intensified spatial control in the city (curfews, closures, internal checkpoints, market shutdowns), normalizing “security” governance patterns.
Benjamin Netanyahu was elected Prime Minister; the politics of partial implementation and opposition to Oslo shaped new governance arrangements in Hebron.

Jan 15. The Hebron Protocol split Hebron into sectors; H2 came under full Israeli military control with intensified checkpoints and “settler-only” corridors—becoming a model for rural “administrative expulsion” in the South Hebron Hills.
Sept 28. The Second Intifada erupted after Ariel Sharon’s visit to the Al-Aqsa compound; the West Bank entered renewed militarization.
During Operation Defensive Shield, Israel effectively re-occupied major West Bank cities; Oslo-era civil arrangements were sidelined.
Feb 8. A declared ceasefire formally ended the Second Intifada, but control shifted into finer-grained administrative enforcement (surveys, planning, demolitions, permit policing).

Feb 17. The Israeli Civil Administration and army executed the first formal demolition order in Umm al-Kheir, demolishing homes and livestock structures without alternative shelter; repeated demolitions became a recurring administrative practice.
